You have $n$ friends, and you want to take $m$ pictures. Each picture must have exactly two friends in it, and no two pictures can have the same two friends. 

The attractiveness of a picture with friends $i$ and $j$ is the bitwise XOR of their attractiveness values ($a_i \oplus a_j$).

You want to choose the friends for each picture so that the total attractiveness of all the pictures is as high as possible.  Calculate this maximum total attractiveness modulo $10^9 + 7$. 

**Input:**

* The first line contains two integers, $n$ (the number of friends) and $m$ (the number of pictures).
* The second line contains $n$ space-separated integers, $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ (the attractiveness of each friend).

**Output:**

* The only line of output should contain the maximum total attractiveness modulo $10^9 + 7$.

You have a group of people, each with a unique score. You want to take pairs of pictures of these people.  The score of a picture is the sum of the scores of the two people in it.  Find the best set of pairs to take pictures of to maximize the total score of all the pictures.
